articles.headline: Judge in Texas Partly Rejects Abortion Law
articles.snippet: The ruling in Federal District Court rejected a provision requiring doctors at abortion clinics to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.
articles.abstract: The ruling in Federal District Court rejected a provision requiring doctors at abortion clinics to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas on Monday blocked an important part of the state’s restrictive new abortion law, which would have required doctors performing the procedure to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

articles.headline: Apple’s Profit Falls Despite Higher Sales of iPhones
articles.snippet: The company said its revenue rose, and that it sold 33.8 million iPhones, up from 26.9 million iPhones in the same quarter last year.
articles.abstract: The company said its revenue rose, and that it sold 33.8 million iPhones, up from 26.9 million iPhones in the same quarter last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple now has more product offerings. And Apple now sells its products in more places. But for the third consecutive quarter, Apple does not have more profit.

articles.headline: The International Fate of ‘12 Years’
articles.snippet: The movie industry is waiting to see if “12 Years a Slave,” a story focusing on an African-American, can garner a global audience.
articles.abstract: The movie industry is waiting to see if “12 Years a Slave,” a story focusing on an African-American, can garner a global audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A darling of the movie awards set, “12 Years a Slave” could make history as the first film by a black director to win the best picture Oscar.

articles.headline: Ryanair, Scorned in Europe, Turns on the Charm
articles.snippet: Michael O’Leary, chief of the budget airline, has vowed to fix what makes Europe’s biggest and most profitable carrier also one of its most reviled.
articles.abstract: Michael O’Leary, chief of the budget airline, has vowed to fix what makes Europe’s biggest and most profitable carrier also one of its most reviled.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Charging 60 euros, or $82, for carry-on bags deemed too large to go in the cabin.

articles.headline: Warily, Schools Watch Students on the Internet
articles.snippet: New ways to monitor students around the clock raise questions about whether educators can or should legally discipline children for online outbursts.
articles.abstract: New ways to monitor students around the clock raise questions about whether educators can or should legally discipline children for online outbursts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, a school principal’s job was to make sure students were not creating a ruckus in the hallways or smoking in the bathroom. Vigilance ended at the schoolhouse gates.

articles.headline: Microcredit for Americans
articles.snippet: Microloans, born of anti-poverty efforts in developing countries, are attracting American clients who do not qualify for credit cards or traditional bank loans.
articles.abstract: Microloans, born of anti-poverty efforts in developing countries, are attracting American clients who do not qualify for credit cards or traditional bank loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday, dozens of Latina immigrants clustered in a small, noisy second-floor office in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens, waiting for one of a half-dozen loan officers to call their names and hand over a check. Children loitered in the stairwell or sprawled, calflike, over their mothers’ laps.

articles.headline: Frenzy of Deals, Once Expected, Seems to Fizzle
articles.snippet: Prognostications of a return to deal-making have turned out to be wrong, very wrong. And deal-making may not be coming back anytime soon.
articles.abstract: Prognostications of a return to deal-making have turned out to be wrong, very wrong. And deal-making may not be coming back anytime soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was mere months ago when headlines were blaring news of the return of merger mania.

articles.headline: Ohio Governor Defies G.O.P. With Defense of Social Safety Net
articles.snippet: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio has critiqued his party’s views on poverty programs and moved to expand Medicaid in his state.
articles.abstract: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio has critiqued his party’s views on poverty programs and moved to expand Medicaid in his state.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In his grand Statehouse office beneath a bust of Lincoln, Gov. John R. Kasich let loose on fellow Republicans in Washington.

articles.headline: House, Set to Vote on 2 Bills, Is Seen as an Ally of Wall St.
articles.snippet: Legislation that would undercut new financial regulations is part of a campaign among Republicans and business-friendly Democrats against the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.abstract: Legislation that would undercut new financial regulations is part of a campaign among Republicans and business-friendly Democrats against the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON –– To Wall Street, this town might seem like enemy territory. But even as federal regulators and prosecutors extract multibillion-dollar penalties from the nation’s biggest banks, Wall Street can rely on at least one ally here: the House of Representatives.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Obama May Ban Spying on Heads of Allied States
articles.snippet: President Obama was poised to order the ban in response to a deepening diplomatic crisis over reports that the National Security Agency had for years targeted the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
articles.abstract: President Obama was poised to order the ban in response to a deepening diplomatic crisis over reports that the National Security Agency had for years targeted the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is poised to order the National Security Agency to stop eavesdropping on the leaders of American allies, administration and congressional officials said Monday, responding to a deepening diplomatic crisis over reports that the agency had for years targeted the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: U.S. Disrupts Afghans’ Tack on Militants
articles.snippet: Afghanistan’s attempt to gain leverage over Pakistan by cultivating an alliance with the Pakistan Taliban was discovered by the United States, which raided a convoy carrying a senior militant in the latest flash point between the nations.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan’s attempt to gain leverage over Pakistan by cultivating an alliance with the Pakistan Taliban was discovered by the United States, which raided a convoy carrying a senior militant in the latest flash point between the nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bungled attempt by the Afghan government to cultivate a shadowy alliance with Islamist militants escalated into the latest flash point in the troubled relationship between Afghanistan and the United States, according to new accounts by officials from both countries.

articles.headline: For Once-Mighty Sears, Pictures of Decay
articles.snippet: Sears said it was looking to split off its Lands’ End and Sears Auto Center brands, and its shares rose almost 12 percent on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Sears said it was looking to split off its Lands’ End and Sears Auto Center brands, and its shares rose almost 12 percent on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | When Brian Sozzi, the chief executive of Belus Capital Advisors, visited Sears locations in New York and New Jersey this month, he said, he found barren shelves, haphazard displays and badly stained carpets.

articles.headline: Dutch Bank Settles Case Over Libor Deceptions
articles.snippet: As part of the settlement, the second-largest agreement in the interest-rate scandal, the Dutch lender reached a so-called deferred prosecution agreement.
articles.abstract: As part of the settlement, the second-largest agreement in the interest-rate scandal, the Dutch lender reached a so-called deferred prosecution agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Dutch lender Rabobank admitted on Tuesday to criminal wrongdoing by its employees and agreed to pay more than $1 billion in criminal and civil penalties to settle investigations by United States, British and other authorities into its role in setting global benchmark interest rates. Its chief executive stepped down immediately.
